Situation1: The partner seems mildly stressed after a routine workday.
Situation2: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Story: I glance at my phone, seeing a text from Mia: “Rough day. Can we talk?” I know she needs me to listen, to be present, to reassure her that everything will be okay. But just as I’m about to call her, my headset buzzes—another customer on the line. This one’s voice is sharp, frustration simmering as he questions every detail of the promotion I’m offering. “How do I know this isn’t a scam? Explain it again, from the top,” he demands. My manager expects me to stay calm, persuasive, and thorough, no matter how difficult the call. I feel my chest tighten. Mia’s waiting for comfort, for me to be the boyfriend who listens and cares. But right now, I’m supposed to be the telemarketer who never loses composure, who answers every objection with patience. I stare at the blinking cursor on my screen, torn between the need to support the person I love and the pressure to perform at work. My heart pounds as I try to figure out who needs me more in this moment.
